characters: INT/EXT. RUE DE L'HOMME ARMEE/RUE DE LA CHANVRERIE/C

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RISE UP out of the iron-grey surface of the ocean, seethi in the wind, towards the shore. Winter rain slices the ai Ahead, the port of Toulon, home of the French navy. A for of tall masted warships. The great ships heave at anchor, the wind whipping their rigging. Through the sea spray we see the great ribs of warships under construction, and warships being refitted.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE CAPTION
dialogues.text: Toulon Home port of the French navy

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Storm-lashed sea and driving rain. A great wave rises up and hammers down. As it recedes we see the figures of men heaving on great ropes, the sea water streaming down over their faces. The harsh storm light catches glints of meta these men are CONVICTS, chained by manacles, heads shaved wearing red shirts with prison numbers crudely stitched onto them. Now we see that the ropes run up to a ship that is being hauled ashore - a storm-damaged man-of-war, its masts broken, rising and falling on the surge. As yet another great wave rolls over the convicts, we follow the straining ropes down into the base of the slipway, and find the convict JEAN VALJEAN, up to his wai in water, chained by two sets of manacles, as the rain an spray and wind scream round him. A great brute of a man, seems to feel nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The convicts sing in time with the rhythmic pulls on the rope -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha - Ha -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha - Ha - Look down, look down Don't look them in the eye

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down You're here until you die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No God above And Hell alone below

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down There's twenty years to go. The camera RISES UP to find JAVERT, the officer in charge of the convict workforce, looking on, his face rain-lashe and expressionless. He stands above the men on the top of the dock, as lines of convicts labour beneath him on the steep steps of the dock wall. Behind Javert, through the storm rain we glimpse a forest half-built ships, their ribbed frames like great skeleton the mist. FOREGROUND convicts are at work on another ship that is almost completed, labouring in the crashing spray.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done no wrong Sweet Jesus, hear my prayer!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down Sweet Jesus doesn't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she'll wait I know that she'll be true -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down They've all forgotten you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I get free You won't see me Here for dust!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down Don't look'em in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long, O Lord Before you let me die?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down You'll always be a slave. Look down, look down You're standing in your grave. With a last great heave the lines of convicts haul the damaged ship onto the slipway. CRACK! The stern flagpole of the ship snaps in a vicious of wind and crashes down into the shallow water near Valj Javert sees and points his stick at Valjean in silent command. Valjean stares back for a beat, defying him. The drops down into the seething water and re-emerges with th great mast in his hands, held over his head. His head bre water with his bitter gaze still on Javert, as he throws mast ashore in a deliberate display of strength. Javert nods to the guards, and they begin to form the chained men into lines to return to their prison. The sto is passing now, blown by the driving wind. Javert approaches Jean Valjean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now Prisoner 24601.                                      Your time is up And your parole's begun. You know what that means?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It means I'm free.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! It means you get                                     Your yellow ticket-of-leave. He hands Valjean a folded yellow paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This badge of shame You'll show it everywhere. It warns you're a dangerous man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I stole a loaf of bread My sister's child was close to death And we were starving.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You will starve again Unless you learn the meaning of the law.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know the meaning of those nineteen years A slave of the law!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five years for what you did, The rest because you tried to run. Yes, 24601!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Jean Valjean!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I'm Javert! Do not forget my name. Do not forget me -
He strides away to command the lines of convicts as they' marched away. Valjean walks away, hardly able to take in that he is free at last. The convicts sing as he goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look down, look down You'll always be a slave. Look down, look down You're standing in your grave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean makes his way up a rising track, a worn knapsack his back. He comes to a stop at the top of the hill, and there before him, lit by the rising sun, spreads a wide vista of fields and towns and villages, stretching into t distance, with the snow capped Alps beyond. Behind and below him lies Toulon at the sea's edge. As we hear the musical theme ('Freedom is Mine'), we see for the first time the darkness in his face give way to a new hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Freedom at last - How strange the taste! Never forget the years - the waste, Nor forgive them for what they've done. They are the guilty - Everyone! The day begins (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now lets see What this new world Will do for me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean strides down the long rising road, pulling his th coat close round him against the cold winter wind. He passes a long line of labourers working. He approaches the OVERSEER. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur can I help? A day's work? The overseer notices shaved hair showing under his cap. OVERSEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take your hat off. Valjean takes his hat off, revealing his shaved and scarr head. OVERSEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Passport. The overseer scans the yellow paper, and hands it back. OVERSEER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No work here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean slogs on up the rising track into the mountains. Snow on the ground here, and darkness falling. He looks up and sees ahead a village built on a rock clif its lights twinkling, the snowy mountains rising behind. The tower of its handsome church rises up like a promise refuge. This is Digne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean enters Digne. As he drinks from the fountain, he a guard standing outside the Mairie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean stands waiting. The officer fastidiously writes d the name of Valjean in his huge ledger and the name of th town in his passport. The officer signs and stamps the passport. OFFICER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean. The officer hands back the passport. Valjean leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean walks down the high street, spies the warm glow o inn and enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean sits in the corner, his hat low over his head. He eyes hungrily a group of cart drivers tucking into a roas meal by a roaring fire place. The innkeeper serves him a beer. As he reaches for it his coat sleeve rides up to reveal his wrist, calloused and scarred by manacles. The innkeeper eyes him warily. He discusses Valjean with two other men, then asks for his paper. Sees the phrase "Extremely Dangerous". VALJEAN'S POV - From the yellow paper in the innkeeper's hands up to the innkeeper's face. A blank stare, a shrug refusal. INNKEEPER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My inn is full.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean moves off wearily through the village. As he pass down the narrow street, faces peer at him from doorways, but the doors close when he goes by. A shadowy figure follows him. Word has spread that he's a `dangerous man'. Passing the uncurtained window of a cottage, he comes to stop. Through the window he sees a scene that breaks his heart: a father at a table by lamplight, his young wife before him, his children on either side. Nothing special, and yet everything he's never had.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He stops at the local jail. An iron chain attached to a b hangs from the prison door. He rings. A grate slides open

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jailer. Would you let me stay here for tonight? JAILER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a prison, not an inn. Get yourself arrested. Then we will open up for you. The grate slides shut. As Jean Valjean walks away, some children who have been following begin throwing stones at him. He threatens them with his stick and they scatter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sees over a garden wall a low doorway in a stone turre Valjean stoops through the doorway and lies down on some straw. He hears a ferocious growl and sees the head of an enormous mastiff. It is a dog kennel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow falling as Valjean makes his way down the road, hung weary, moving slowly, his trousers ripped and bloody from where the dog has bitten him. At the end of a road, the snow-covered church; beside it, dark churchyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Snow-covered gravestones in moonlight. Exhausted, Valjean collapses to the ground and huddles himself into the shelter of a doorway. A lantern glows in the dark. The lantern approaches, throwing shadows. Its little circle of light comes to res on the crumpled figure of Valjean. He stirs and opens his eyes. VALJEAN'S POV - The glow of the lantern in the darkness. Beyond it, the half-seen features of a kind old man. The BISHOP. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come in, sir, for you are weary And the night is cold out here. Though our lives are very humble What we have we have to share. Bewildered, fearful, suspicious, Valjean gets up and goes with the Bishop into the house by the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A simple table on which is laid out bread and wine, with silver cutlery. Two silver candlesticks light the room, illuminating walls painted with religious scenes. The Bis ushers the bewildered Valjean into the room. The bishop's sister Madame Baptistine stands. Valjean hesitates. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is wine here to revive you. There is bread to make you strong. There's a bed to rest till morning - Rest from pain, and rest from wrong.                                                   BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sit, my brother. The Bishop gestures to the housekeeper Madame Magloire. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame, set one more place. (to Valjean)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please sit. The Bishop gently takes his arm and draws him into a chai Valjean sits, and the Housekeeper lays food before him. Famished, Valjean eats like an animal. The Bishop says a short grace. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May the Lord bless the food we eat                       today. Bless our dear sister and                         our honoured guest. (To Valjean)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, eat. Where are you travelling to my brother? VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pontarlier. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that where your family is? VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. The destination is compulsory. That is where the Law sends me. I have no home. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then let this be your home, for as long as you need it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop leads Valjean to a bedroom where the walls are also painted with religious imagery. Across the passage, Valjean sees the open door to the Bishop's own bedroom. There the Housekeeper is putting the table silver away in cupboard. He turns to see a bed made up with clean white linen waiting for him. He hasn't slept in such a bed ever in hi life. But the Bishop is smiling, offering it to him. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sleep well. Tomorrow morning before you leave you will have a cup of milk from our cows, nice and hot. The Bishop turns away to go to sleep. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me sleep here next to you? How do you know I'm not a murderer? Valjean laughs a strange laugh. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God will take care of that.

dialogues.speaker: LATER THAT NIGHT -
dialogues.text: Valjean lies on the bed, fully dressed, deeply asleep. Outside a dog barks. Valjean's eyes snap open. The first thing he sees by the light of the moon is an image of God the Father gazing do on him from the painted ceiling. In panic, fearing judgement, he sits bolt upright. Then he looks round, and remembers. He gets out of bed, and opens the door. There, across the narrow passage, the door stands open to the Bishop's bedroom. In the moonlight, he sees the Bisho lying asleep. Above his bed, the cupboard where the silve is kept. Valjean moves silently into the Bishop's room, holding a metal miner's spike which he pulls from his bag. The floo boards creak. He looks down at the old man, holding his breath, but the bishop is peacefully and innocently aslee He reaches up to the cupboard. It is unlocked. The cupboa door opens with a sharp cracking sound. The Bishop, disturbed in his sleep, moves a little. At once Valjean i over him, like a wild animal, spike raised to strike shou he wake. The Bishop sleeps on. The moon comes out and lights up his beautific, smiling face. Valjean is thrown. He turns back and opens the cupboard door fully: there is the silver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carefully he picks it out, fearful of every clink. One la look at the sleeping old man, and he makes a run for the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean rushes out of the back door of the house. He crosses the graveyard, scrambles over a back wall, and he gone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Bishop is coming in from morning Mass in his vestment when the door bursts open and two policemen drag Valjean before him. Valjean hangs his head, unable to meet the Bishop's eyes. CONSTABLE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsignor, we caught the thief red-handed! He has the nerve to say you gave him all this! He upends Valjean's kitbag, and the silver tumbles out. The Bishop looks from the silver to Valjean. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That is right. Amazed, Valjean looks up. BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But my friend, you left so early, You forgot I gave these also. Would you leave the best behind? The old Bishop is holding out the two silver candlesticks BISHOP (to policemen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Messieurs, release him. For this man has spoken true. I commend you for your duty Now God's blessing go with you. Silenced by the Bishop's gentle tones, the policemen turn and leave. Valjean, utterly bewildered, takes the silver candlestick BISHOP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But remember this, my brother - See in this some higher plan. You must use this precious silver To become an honest man. By the witness of the martyrs, (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BISHOP (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the passion and the blood, God has raised you out of darkness - I have bought your soul for God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean kneels in the church. He takes out his yellow passport and stares at it. He turns towards the altar, and the crucifix above it. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What have I done? Sweet Jesus, what have I done? Become a thief in the night Become a dog on the run! And have I fallen so far And is the hour so late That nothing remains but the cry of my hate? The cries in the dark that nobody hears Here where I stand at the turning of the years. If there's another way to go I missed it twenty long years ago. My life was a war that could never be won. They gave me a number and murdered Valjean When they chained me and left me for dead Just for stealing a mouthful of bread!                                                   Yet why did I allow this man To touch my soul and teach me love? He treated me like any other He gave me his trust He called me brother. My life he claims for God above... Can such things be? For I had come to hate the world - This world that always hated me! Take an eye for an eye! Turn your heart into stone! This is all I have lived for! This is all I have known! One word from him and I'd be back Beneath the lash, upon the rack. Instead he offers me my freedom! (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel my shame inside me like a knife. He told me that I have a soul... How does he know? What spirit comes to move my life? Is there another way to go? Slowly, he examines the yellow passport and raises it hig as if to the altar. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am reaching, but I fall And the night is closing in... As I stare into the void - To the whirlpool of my sin. Valjean stands and turns, walking fast to the door of the church. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll escape now from that world - From the world of Jean Valjean. Jean Valjean is nothing now!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean comes out of the church into the graveyard and reaches a bell set on the edge of a promontory. Below lie the steep drop down the mountainside to the dark valley below. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another story must begin! He rips the yellow paper into pieces and throws the piece out over the valley. The scraps flutter in the wind. FOLLOW the scraps of yellow paper as they dance in the wi then fall away into the void below. One scrap of paper dances upwards in the sunlight. We follow this and accelerate upwards leaving Valjean and the town of Digne far below, towards the sun gloriously breaking through th heavens with the alps beyond. The camera then starts to tumble back down through mist and cloud below - through time and space - down to discover -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The camera hurtling towards three horses riding down a lo muddy road on a flat plain towards the walled town of Montreuil-sur-Mer. Montreuil sits on an estuary leading o to the sea. We see ships sitting in low tide on the mud o the estuary along the dockside of the town, and red brick factory buildings.

dialogues.speaker: SUPERIMPOSE CAPTION
dialogues.text: Eight years later

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montreuil-sur-Mer, 1823. The camera closes in to ground level to reveal the horseriders: Javert, flanked by two policemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the riders enter the walled town we see the poor clust around the gates - destitute and sick people clammering t get in. BEGGARS' CHORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day you're another day older And that's all you can say for the life of the poor. It's a struggle! It's a war! And there's nothing that anyone's giving. One more day standing about - What is it for? One day less to be living. Javert sees the destitution of the people. Expressionless as ever. BEGGARS' CHORUS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day you're another day colder And the shirt on your back doesn't keep out the chill. And the righteous hurry past They don't hear the little ones crying And the plague is coming on fast Ready to kill - One day nearer to dying! TRACK PAST a plague victim, wrapped in a shroud, being th onto a cart. The police enter the harbour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The beggars are pushed back as the gates open and close f the police.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEGGARS' CHORUS                                  At the end of the day there's another day dawning And the sun in the morning is waiting to rise Like the waves crash on the sand Like a storm that'll break any second There's a hunger in the land There's a reckoning still to be reckoned And there's gonna be hell to pay At the end of the day!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert looks round at the factory buildings, the boats in the harbour, the poor clamouring behind him, and rides on

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Heavy carts wait to be loaded with wooden crates of goods Workmen carry the crates out of the factory as the FOREMA strides in through the doors, gesturing to a cart driver, FAUCHELEVENT, who's taking a quick rest on a crate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The foreman passes men packing boxes on tables and loadin boxes onto crates. He passes through a door under a first floor office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The long work space is full of tables at which conservatively dressed women are working, making jewelry out of shellac, a black resin which looks like jet. An impressive sight: obviously a very successful business. A wooden staircase climbs one wall to a glass-windowed business office. The figure of a man within. FOREMAN (flirtatiously, to women)                              At the end of the day you get nothing for nothing! Sitting flat on your bum doesn't buy any bread! FACTORY WOMAN 4                                  There are children back at home - FACTORY WOMAN 2                                  And the children have got to be fed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACTORY WOMAN 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you're lucky to be in a job - The Foreman has stopped beside FANTINE, a pretty young wo As he leans over to whisper in her ear Fantine, surprised pricks her finger with her needle. FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quietly, to Fantine)                               And in a bed! FACTORY WOMAN 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Fantine, as a warning)                          And we're counting our blessings!                       The Foreman continues his rounds, encouraging the women t speed up their work. FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day just be glad                      to be working For a master who cares for the lives of the poor.                                      FACTORY WOMAN 7

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a riddle.. FACTORY WOMAN 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's no fool.. FACTORY WOMAN 6

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's the answer to anyone's prayer FACTORY WOMAN 8

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he paid for the brand new                           school FACTORY WOMAN 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's no wonder they made him the mayor! FACTORY WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bless the man who leads the way! At the end of the day! They get on with their tasks, all glancing up at the boss the office above. The Foreman returns to Fantine, trying to help her. MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you seen how the foreman is fuming today                                            With his terrible breath and his wandering hands?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACTORY WOMAN 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's because little Fantine won't give him his way. FACTORY WOMAN 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look at his trousers, you'll see where he stands! FACTORY WOMAN 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the boss, he never knows That the foreman is always on                           heat. MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If Fantine doesn't look out, Watch how she goes, She'll be out on the street!                            The Foreman rings a bell, announcing the end of the work The women start to take off their overalls and pack up th tools for the day. FACTORY WOMEN/FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day its another day over With enough in your pocket to last for a week                                              Pay the landlord, pay the shop                          Keep on working as long as you're                       able                                                    Keep on working till you drop                           Or it's back to the crumbs off the table                                                   Well, you've got to pay your way                        At the end of the day!                                  The women queue up to be paid by the Foreman at the door. Fantine has taken out a letter. The main factory woman snatches the letter away from Fantine. MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what have we here, little innocent sister? The letter is passed surreptitiously down the line of wom workers. MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Fantine, let's have all the news. (reading) `Dear Fantine, you must send us more money, Your child needs a doctor, There's no time to lose.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give that letter to me It is none of your business. With a husband at home And a bit on the side! Is there anyone here Who can swear before God She has nothing to fear? She has nothing to hide? The main factory woman starts to take Fantine's letter ov to the Foreman. Fantine tries to get the letter back. The women scuffle. The owner enters the factory floor. We see him only from behind: a well-dressed prosperous man. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is this fighting all about? Will someone tear these two apart? This is a factory, not a circus. As he sings, the CAMERA MOVES ROUND to discover him. Clea shaven, well-fed, transformed: it's Valjean. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now come on, ladies, settle down. I run a business of repute. Suddenly Valjean sees Javert appear on the first floor balcony of his office. His world drops away. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the foreman) Deal with this, Foreman.                               Be as patient as you can.                              He walks back to the stairs up to his office. On the factory floor - FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now someone say how this began! The factory women all turn on Fantine. FANTINE/FACTORY WOMAN 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day she's the one who began it! MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a kid that she's hiding                        in some little town. FACTORY WOMAN 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a man she has to pay

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can guess how she picks up the extra - You can bet she's earning her keep Sleeping around! And the boss wouldn't like it. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's true there's a child And the child is my daughter And her father abandoned us, Leaving us flat. Now she lives with an innkeeper man and his wife And I pay for the child. What's the matter with that? Fantine continues to defend herself to the Foreman, as th women sing - FACTORY WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the end of the day she'll be nothing but trouble And there's trouble for all when there's trouble for one! While we're earning our daily bread She's the one with her hands in the butter - You must send the slut away Or we're all going to end in the gutter And it's us who'll have to pay At the end of the day! The Foreman pulls Fantine away. FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have known the bitch could bite! I might have known the cat had claws! I might have guessed your little secret! Ah yes, the virtuous Fantine Who keeps herself so pure and clean - You'd be the cause, I had no doubt Of any trouble hereabout. You play a virgin in the light But need no urging in the night! MAIN FACTORY WOMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's been laughing at you While she's having her men!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FACTORY WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll be nothing but trouble again and again! FACTORY WOMAN 5

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must sack her today! FACTORY WOMEN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sack the girl today! FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, my girl! On your way! Below, Fantine turns and calls to Valjean in his office above with a pitiful cry. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieur Mayor, help me! I have a child! Valjean hears the cry, but he has other concerns. He turn round to face Javert. Javert stares at him. On the factory floor below, the Foreman hustles Fantine out, as she struggles against him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert bows. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I introduce myself, Inspector of Police. I've come to take the watch I'm here to keep the peace. Please know me as Javert. I'm here at your command With honour due to each. With justice in our hands No man's beyond our reach. Let all beware. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, sir Come guard our laws I'm sure we're here In common cause. Javert turns to look through the high window onto the men factory floor below. The last men are leaving for the day JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done the city proud, You've raised their banner high. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAVERT (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You manufacture gems That anyone can buy Your people thrive. Valjean shows some demonstration samples of their work. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The dignity of toil To stay alive. Javert is puzzled. He's sure he recognises Valjean, but from where? JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It seems to me We may have met. Valjean throws him a sharp glance. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your face is not a face I would forget. A CRASH from outside in the yard - shouts -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean and Javert hurry out across the factory yard and down the muddy track beyond to discover - A heavily laden cart has toppled onto the cart driver - Fauchelevent, the worker seen before taking a rest on a crate. The   cart driver and the Foreman are trying to lift the off   the crushed man, but it's too heavy, and the ground too   soft. Fauchelevent screams as the cart slowly sinks the   mud. Valjean, Javert and Javert's assistant all hurry to help, but they can't get a proper purchase in the spongy ground All the time the cart is sinking further, pushing Fauchelevent deeper into the mud that will soon bury him. Then Valjean sees a way. At one end the wheels of the car have stopped sinking - the ground is harder here. He thro himself under the cart at this higher end, and braces himself to lift it from beneath. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get back! It may fall! FOREMAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Monsieur le Mayor! CROWD

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll kill you as well!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert stands back and looks on. As he looks, we see a memory stirring in him. JAVERT'S POV - Valjean's posture beneath the cart is exactly the same as the convict beneath the fallen mast. The same crouching power. The same almost-suicidal determination. Valjean sees Javert looking at him, and knows exactly wha he's thinking. For a moment he hesitates. Then he hears Fauchelevent's choking scream as the mud gags his mouth. Valjean strains every muscle, and slowly one end of the cart begins to rise. As soon as it clears the crushed and gasping man, the others pull him clear. Valjean lets the cart down again, and climbs out. As he brushes himself down he finds Javert staring at him. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can this be true? I don't believe what I see! A man your age To be as strong as you are! A memory stirs...                                     You make me think of a man                            From years ago                                        A man who broke his parole..                          He disappeared.                                       He shakes his head, realising how absurd his suspicions are. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forgive me, sir. I would not dare - VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say what you must. Don't leave it there. Valjean holds Javert's gaze, challenging him to say more. Javert is not yet confident enough to continue. Valjean goes to help Fauchelevent. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me help you up.                                   Fauchelevent groans as he rises. FAUCHELEVENT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor, you come from God! You are a saint! VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more cart driving for you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert stares. He can't rid himself of his suspicion. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor. He draws himself up and gives a bow. As he walks away, he discusses something with his assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine makes her way to the harbour wall. Beggars shelte the tunnels under the red brick buildings.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine makes her way down   wet slimy steps. This leads alleyway that runs down to   the harbour and three ships on the mud at low tide. At   the far end, the largest is rotting hulk of a vast old   warship. A single whore sits doorway. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, is this where the Pawnbrokers is? WHORE 1                                           (pointing)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just there. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. Drunken sailors spill out into the alleyway below. The first sailor is trying to find the whorehouse. SAILOR 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I smell women! Smell'em in the air! Think I'll drop my anchor In that harbour over there! They spot Fantine, mistaking her for a whore. Fantine pre on down the steps, trying to ignore the sailors. SAILOR 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely ladies! Love `em till your broke! Seven months at sea can make you Hungry for a poke! The sailors then see whores start to appear from the shad of warehouse doorways. SAILOR 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even stokers need a little stoke!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A man with no legs, reacting to the sailors, cranks up an organ-grinder and from doorways and overhead windows harbour whores appear and tout for business. A man selling dentures stands by his cart and we hear fragments of his sales pitch.

dialogues.speaker: WHORES TOOTH MAN
dialogues.text: Lovely ladies                   Lovely dentures Waiting for a bite!             Guaranteed to bite Waiting for the customers       They clean up real easy Who only come at night.         You can take them out at Lovely ladies                   night Ready for the call,             Sell your teeth here make Standing up or lying down       pretty sum Or any way at all -             Best Tooth Man in the har

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bargain prices up against the   Guaranteed no painful gum wall!                           Bargain prices up against wall!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During the above chorus, Fantine sells a locket containin cutting of Cosette's hair to the pawnbroker. PAWNBROKER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello sweetheart, I'll give you                         four francs.                                            FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's worth at least ten.                                The pawnbroker goes back in his shop and Fantine watches whores. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, five.                                          The pawnbroker takes the locket in exchange for the money An old woman leers at Fantine from the shadows, beckoning She approaches Fantine, reaching out to stroke her hair. HAIR CRONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What pretty hair! What pretty locks you've got                            there! What luck you got. It's worth a centime, my dear! I'll take the lot! FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't touch me! Leave me alone! HAIR CRONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's make a price. I'll give you all of ten francs. Just think of that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It pays a debt... HAIR CRONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just think of that. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What can I do? It pays a debt. Ten francs may save my poor Cosette. The hair crone leads Fantine down to her shop at the base the stairs. Fantine is sat on a low stool. She bows her head before t hair crone, who at once whips out a razor blade and cuts off her hair at the roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine walks down the steps with short hair, mocked by t voices of the whores on either side. A PIMP and the HEAD WHORE watch her progress as the organ grinder grinds out the music. Whores sing from the warehouse doorways, from on top of t spars of the ships, writhing around figureheads and from rotting ship. The few men in the street choose their whores and disappe by the end of the chorus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely ladies                     Lovely dentures guarant Waiting in the dark.              bite Ready for a thick one             They clean up real easy Or a quick one in the park.       You can take them out a night

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HEAD WHORE                 Lovely teeth dear shining Long time, short time             like the stars Anytime my dear!                  I'll whip em out quite Cost a little extra               quickly If you want to take all year      And I won't leave any s

dialogues.speaker: WHORES
dialogues.text: Quick and cheap is underneath the pier Fantine reaches the hair crone. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please, you wouldn't have any work for me would you? Please, I sold you my hair. I could do anything. The hair crone points at the head whore and the tooth man

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HAIR CRONE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go and see them. Fantine looks towards the tooth man and the head whore.

dialogues.speaker: TOOTH MAN HEAD WHORE
dialogues.text: Come over here,                   Come here my dear. I'll pay well for your youth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay ten francs for a tooth. Fantine heads to the tooth man. TOOTH MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have, my dear, The clear advantage of youth. HEAD WHORE                                        (whispers)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just the back ones. TOOTH MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pain won't last, You'll still be able to bite. She grabs Fantine's cheeks and forces open her mouth to inspect her teeth. TOOTH MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do it fast, I know my business all right. It's worth a go. The pimp pushes her down. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll pay me first What I am due. TOOTH MAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll get twice If I take two! She opens her mouth, and the pincers go in, as everyone gathers round to watch. Fantine screams as the first toot is removed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pimp is passing among the whores, checking that they' all fit for business. WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, we're weary, Sick enough to drop! LOVELY LADY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Belly burns like fire, Will the bleeding ever stop!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheer up, deary! Show a happy face! Plenty more like you here If you can't keep up the pace.                         LOVELY LADY 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Only joking! Deary knows her place! The pimp gestures at Fantine, now slumped in a doorway, h cropped head in her hands. A shy captain watches Fantine. The pimp notices. PIMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gimme the dirt - Who's that bit over there? WHORE 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A bit of skirt, She's the one sold her hair. HEAD WHORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's got a kid, Sends her all that she can. PIMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might've known There is always some man. He moves in on Fantine. PIMP

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely lady, come along and join us! Lovely lady! Fantine looks up, a trickle of blood in one corner of her mouth. The whores cluster round her, hands reaching out t draw her in to their world. On the rotting warship, more whores appear out of the gaps of the hull to sing the chorus. WHORE 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, dearie, why all the                           fuss?                                                  WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... why all the fuss.                                  WHORE 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're no grander than the rest of us. WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... than the rest of us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHORE 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Life has dropped you at the bottom of the heap. WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...at the bottom of the heap.                          Whore 3 bites her fingertip and applies her blood to roug Fantine's cheeks. HEAD WHORE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Join your sisters - WHORE 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make money in your sleep! WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... make money in your sleep.                          WHORE 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, dearie, Show him what you've got! WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... show him what you've got.                          WHORE 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right, dearie, Let him have the lot! WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...let him have the lot.                               The whores perform for the benefit of Fantine on the orde of the head whore, as the head whore leads her towards th hulk. WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Old men, young men, take'em as they come! Harbour rats and alley cats And every kind of scum! Poor men, rich men, leaders of the land - See them with their trousers off, They're never quite as grand! All it takes is money in your hand! The pimp leads the captain down the middle of the whores Fantine who wears a filthy white dress. The pimp joins th captain and Fantine's hands as the head whore officiates like a twisted wedding ceremony. WHORES

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lovely ladies Going for a song, (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHORES (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got a lot of callers But they never stay for long... Fantine puts on a show of courage as she leads the captai into the ship's hulk, which is a brothel. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Captain, you can wear your shoes. Don't it make a change to have a girl who can't refuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine, pale and frail, her bodice loosened, leads the captain down to the damp dregs of the ship. We see the rotting straw mattress within as they enter, then Fantine lays down. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy money lying on a bed. Just as well they never see The hate that's in your head! Don't they know they're making love To one already dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON a man's hand leaving money. We hear him exit. MO TO FIND Fantine lying alone on the mattress. She pulls herself into a sitting position against the hea of the mattress. She draws her legs up and wraps her arms round her knees, huddling against the misery of the world FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was a time when men were kind, When their voices were soft And their words inviting. There was a time when love was blind And the world was a song And the song was exciting. There was a time... Then it all went wrong. I dreamed a dream in time gone by, When hope was high And life worth living. I dreamed that love would never die. I dreamed that God would be forgiving. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I was young and unafraid And dreams were made and used and wasted. There was no ransom to be paid, No song unsung, no wine untasted. But the tigers come at night With their voices soft as thunder As they tear your hope apart As they turn your dream to shame. He slept a summer by my side, He filled my days with endless wonder. He took my childhood in his stride But he was gone when autumn came. And still I dream he'll come to me! That we will live the years together... But there are dreams that cannot be And there are storms we cannot weather... I had a dream my life would be So different from this hell I'm living - So different now from what it seemed! Now life has killed the dream I dreamed. As she ends her song, her next customer is waiting. The h whore beyond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine is out on the snow and ice-covered quayside, shivering, waiting for trade. She looks pale and sickly, but still attempts an alluring smile. She moves past the anchored ships, beneath the bowsprits, trying pathetically to attract custom. Then she comes to stop, staring. She has seen and recognised Valjean, some way off. He's out in the harbour district. He is talking a beggar. Before he moves on, he hands over some money. As Fantine watches Valjean on his mission of mercy, a wel dressed young man, BAMATABOIS, comes up to her. He arrive with two friends and a valet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's something new. I think I'll give it a try. Come closer, you! I like to see what I buy. The usual price For just one slice of your pie.                        FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want you! No! No, M'sieur! Let me go! BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this a trick? I won't pay more! FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, not at all!                                        BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've got some nerve, you little slut! You've got some gall!                                  It's the same with a tart as it is                     with a grocer                                          The customer sees what he gets in                      advance                                                It's not for the whore to say "yes                     sir" or "no sir"                                       It's not for the harlot to pick and                    to choose or to lead me a dance!                       He pulls her clothing open and laughingly stuffs snow dow her cleavage. Fantine reacts with fury. They fall over in snow and Bamatabois laughs. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll kill you, you bastard! Try any of that! Even a whore who has gone to the bad Won't be had by a rat!                                 Fantine scratches Bamatabois across the face. Bamatabois touches his face and sees the blood on his fingers. His friends drag Fantine against the harbour wall. BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious but aroused)                              By Christ you'll pay for what you've done! This rat will make you bleed, you'll see! I guarantee I'll make you suffer! For this disturbance of the peace For this insult to life and property!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bamatabois suddenly sees that police have arrived. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I beg you, don't report me, sir. I'll do whatever you may want.                       BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make your excuse to the police! Bamatabois' friend drags Fantine towards the police. It's Javert. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me quickly what's the story. Who saw what and why and where? Let him give a full description, Let him answer to Javert! In this nest of whores and vipers Let one speak who saw it all. Who laid hands on this good man here? What's the substance of this brawl? BAMATABOIS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert, would you believe it?                        I was walking, it was dark When this prostitute attacked me You can see she's left her mark! He shows the blood. Javert turns to Fantine. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She will answer for her actions When you make a full report. You may rest assured, M'sieur, That she will answer to the court. Fantine is almost fainting with fear, still racked with occasional spasms of coughing. Unseen by her, Valjean is approaching from behind. Javert's assistants pick Fantine up. Javert covers his mouth with a handkerchief as he approaches Fantine. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a child who sorely needs me, Please, m'sieur, she's but that high. Holy God, is there no mercy? If I go to jail she'll die.                          JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have heard such protestations Every day for twenty years. Let's have no more explanations, (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAVERT (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Save your breath and save your tears. Javert indicates to the two policemen to drag Fantine awa Valjean steps out of the shadows. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment of your time, Javert. I do believe this woman's tale. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor!                                     VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've done your duty. Let her be. She needs a doctor, not a jail. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor!                                     Javert looks on, containing his anger, as Valjean reaches out a hand to Fantine. To Fantine, it's as if he's come t her in a dream - FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can this be? VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where will she end - This child without a friend? He holds Fantine's hands, looking into her face. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've seen your face before. Show me some way to help you. How have you come to grief In such a place as this? FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: M'sieur, don't mock me now, I pray It's hard enough I've lost my pride. You let your foreman send me away. Yes, you were there And turned aside. I never did no wrong. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true what I've done - FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My daughter's close to dying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - to an innocent soul? FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If there's a God above - VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Had I only known then! FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He'd let me die instead. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In His name my task has just begun. I will her to the hospital.                              Valjean picks Fantine up in his arms. Javert is quietly coldly furious. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor!                                       FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bring Cosette back to me. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where is she? FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At an inn in Montfermeil... JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor!                                       VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I will see it done! I will send                          for her immediately!                                     As Valjean and Fantine move away, Javert stares after the then turns and quietly instructs his assistant to follow after them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Javert walks up the steps to his police station his assistant stops him with an urgent letter. JAVERT'S ASSISTANT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From Paris, Monsieur. Javert seizes it, opens it, and reads. As he reads, his expression changes. Appalled, he realizes he's made a terrible mistake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean is at his desk in his office, going through his papers once everyone else has gone, when Javert enters an stands before him. He looks up. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor I have a crime to declare! I have disgraced The uniform that I wear. I've done you wrong, Let no forgiveness be shown. I've been as hard On every rogue I have known. I'll bear the blame, I must be treated Just the same. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand. What is this crime, Javert? JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mistook you for a convict, I have made a false report. Now I learn they've caught the culprit - He's about to face the court. Valjean conceals his shock. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And of course the thief denies it, You'd expect that from a con. But he couldn't run for ever, No, not even Jean Valjean. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say this man denies it all, And gives no sign of understanding or repentance? You say this man is going to trial, And that he's sure to be returned to serve his sentence? JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He will pay, and so must I. Press charges against me, sir! VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have only done your duty It's a minor sin at most. All of us have been mistaken You'll return, sir, to your post.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Must I do as you say? VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's your duty to obey! Javert is about to protest again, but Valjean raises one commanding hand, to indicate his decision is made. Javert gives an abrupt bow, and departs. Left alone, Valjean paces his office, deeply disturbed. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They think that man is me - Without a second glance. This stranger they have found - This man could be my chance! Why should I save his hide? Why should I right this wrong? When I have come so far And struggled for so long? If I speak I am condemned. If I stay silent, I am damned! He goes out onto the balcony that looks down on the empty factory. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the master of hundreds of workers - They all look to me. Can I abandon them? How would they live If I am not free? If I speak they are condemned. If I stay silent, I am damned!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean is sitting staring at the Bishop's candlesticks. Who am I? Can I condemn this man to slavery? Pretend I do not feel his agony? This innocent who bears my face, Who goes to judgement in my place... Who am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean is furiously packing stuff up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I conceal myself for ever more? Pretend I'm not the man I was before? And must my name until I die Be no more than an alibi? 31C   EXT. COUNTRY ROAD - NIGHT. Close on two horses panting. A stopped carriage in a wide night landscape. The driver is Valjean, hesitating. Must I lie? How can I ever face my fellow men? How can I ever face myself again?

dialogues.speaker: 31D INT/EXT. COURTROOM
dialogues.text: Valjean hesitates outside the courtroom and in the lobby the courtroom, pacing back and forth. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My soul belongs to God, I know, I made that bargain long ago. He gave me hope when hope was gone! He gave me strength to journey on! Who am I? Who am I? I'm Jean Valjean! Valjean pushes through the crowds at the back of the courtroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The man accused of being Jean Valjean, a wretched down-an out, stands before the JUDGE. He looks uncannily like the real Valjean. Before the judge has a chance to speak, the doors open and Valjean bursts in. Sensation in the court. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so, your honour, you see it's true That man bears no more guilt than you! Who am I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge is too stunned to respond. The others in the court can't believe what they've just heard. The Mayor of Montreuil-sur-Mer, a convict! VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you don't believe me ask Inspector Javert. He knows where to find me. The judge goes over to Valjean and gently leads him out. JUDGE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Monsieur le Mayor, you are not well, you must come with me, do you have a carriage outside? Monsieur le Mayor, we must get you home to bed immediately!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hospital is in the long attic of Valjean's factory. Valjean hurries into the hospital, breathless. He sees a nursing sister outside Fantine's room. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is her daughter with her? NURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, monsieur. Her guardian sent this. She gives Valjean a note. He reads it with mounting anger VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Money not enough. Send more. Thenardier.' What sort of man is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fantine lies in bed, delirious. She is dressed in pure white. Her eyes are closed. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosette, it's turned so cold! Cosette, it's past your bedtime! You've played the day away And soon it will be night. Fantine's eyes open and she sees Cosette, playing in the room. She looks healthy and is dressed prettily. Come to me, Cosette, the light is fading. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: FANTINE (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you see, the evening star                       appearing?                                            Come to me, and rest against my                       shoulder,                                             How fast the minutes fly away and                     every minute colder?                                  Valjean enters, and sees at once that Fantine is close to the end. He drops to his knees by her bed. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Fantine, Cosette will be                         here soon!                                            Dear Fantine, she will be by your                     side                                                  FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (trying to get out of bed)                        Come Cosette, the night has grown                     so cold!                                              VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (putting her back in bed)                         Be at peace! Be at peace ever more. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Cosette - VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - shall live in my protection. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take her now! She pushes into his hand a scrap of paper on which she's written her wishes. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your child will want for nothing. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good m'sieur, you come from God in heaven. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And none shall ever harm Cosette as long as I am living. Fantine has stopped looking towards the window. All her fading strength is now directed towards Valjean. She trie to reach up to him. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my hand... The night grows ever colder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then I will keep you warm. He wraps her in his arms. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my child I give her to your keeping. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take shelter from the storm. FANTINE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For God's sake, please stay till I am sleeping... And tell Cosette I love her And I'll see her when I wake... Fantine starts to spasm. She sees something over Valjean' shoulder. Valjean doesn't realise. Her eyes go glassy as she passes away. Valjean then hears the unforgettable voi of Javert behind him. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Valjean, at last We see each other plain! `M'sieur le Mayor' You'll wear a different chain! Valjean stands to face Javert. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before you say another word, Javert, Before you chain me up like a slave again, Listen to me! There is something I must do. This woman leaves behind a suffering child. There is none but me who can intercede - In mercy's name, three days are all I need, Then I'll return, I pledge my word! Then I'll return... Javert draws his sword and aims it at Valjean. JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must think me mad! I've hunted you across the years. Men like you can never change - A man such as you! Valjean breaks a section of timber beam from the roof.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The men start to circle each other. They sing at the same time, duelling in song. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe of me what you will There is a duty that I'm sworn to do. You know nothing of my life - All I did was steal some bread. You know nothing of the world - You would sooner see me dead. But not before I see this justice done! JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Men like me can never change. Men like you can never change. No, 24601! My duty is to the law. You have no rights. Come with me, 24601! The two men fight. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am warning you, Javert, I'm a stronger man by far! There is power in me yet! My race is not yet run! JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the wheel has turned around - Jean Valjean is nothing now. Dare you talk to me of crime And the price you had to pay. Every man is born in sin Every man must choose his way. Javert disarms Valjean and drives him backwards towards a attic door. You know nothing of Javert! I was born inside a jail. I was born with scum like you. I am from the gutter too. Valjean is pushed through the doors out onto a wooden loading platform beneath a hoist. Below, the walls of the factory lead straight down to the black sea at high tide. Javert is triumphant. Valjean glances down and pushes back, dropping into the darkness of the ocean. Javert goes to jump after him and cannot bring himself to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert stares into the black sea - there is no sign of Valjean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Javert and various police search the harbourside with lanterns. Valjean, dripping wet, watches from a tunnel under a fact as Fantine's body wrapped in a shroud is dumped on a cart They sing to themselves, continuing their duet without knowing. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this I swear to you tonight - JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is no place for you to hide. VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your child will live within my care - JAVERT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wherever you may hide away - VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I will raise her to the light. JAVERT/VALJEAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I swear to you, I will be there!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The village street is bright with booths set up for a Fro Fair. Families and visitors are out buying baubles, or laughing at the antics of travelling players. Small girls cluster round a stall that displays prettily-dressed doll Amongst them is a prettily-dressed girl of 8 or 9 years: EPONINE. Across the road from this stall stands a shabby inn. A sign lashed to an old cart swinging in the wind reveals t inn to be `The Sergeant of Waterloo'. The inn is still closed despite the small crowd at the fair. MOVE IN on the frosted window of the inn, through which w see a little girl, COSETTE, gazing out at the display of dolls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosette is in the process of sweeping the floor. She's co to a stop, gazing out of the window, mesmerized by the sight of the most beautiful doll in the display, and jealous that Eponine can see it and touch it up close. COSETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a castle on a cloud I like to go there in my sleep. Aren't any floors for me to sweep, Not in my castle on a cloud. Cosette gets out from a hiding place in the wall a knotte grimy rag - this is her "doll", the knot is the doll's he There is a lady all in white Holds me and sings a lullaby. She's nice to see and she's soft to touch (holding doll to her ear                               and whispering)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She says, Cosette, I love you very much. I know   a place where no one's lost I know   a place where no one cries. Crying   at all is not allowed, Not in   my castle on a cloud. Madame Thenardier comes bustling down the stairs in a bad mood. She glowers at little Cosette and changes the close sign from "closed" to "open". MADAME THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now look who's here! The little madam herself, Pretending once again She's been so awfully good! Better not let me catch you slacking! Better not catch my eye! Ten rotten francs your mother sends me - What is that going to buy? Now take that pail, My little Mademoiselle, And go and draw some water from the well. We should never have taken you in In the first place - How stupid the things that we do! Like mother, like daughter, the scum of the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosette goes to put the broom away. Eponine comes in from outside. MADAME THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eponine, come my dear. Eponine, let me see you. You look very well in that little blue hat! There's some little girls who know how to behave And they know what to wear And I'm saying thank heaven for that! Madame Thenardier sees that Cosette far from going is hiding behind the far wall. We see Cosette's frightened eyes peering out from a tiny gap in this wall. MADAME THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still there, Cosette? Your tears will do you no good! I told you to fetch some water from the well in the wood. COSETTE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing through the gap)                            Please do not send me out alone. Not in the darkness on my own. Madame Thenardier imitates Cosette as she sings. MADAME THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (singing through the gap)                            Enough of that, or I'll forget to be nice! You heard me ask for something, And I never ask twice!                                   The innkeeper's gang posing as customers who have been loitering outside come in, explaining to a fifth man who newer recruit a story from Monsieur Thenardier's past. Ma Thenardier goes outside to open up the rather pathetic fr fair stall on the porch of the inn. CUSTOMER 1

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine host Thenardier He was there, so they say, At the field of Waterloo. CUSTOMER 2

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got there, it's true, When the fight was all through But he knew just what to do. CUSTOMER 3

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Crawling through the mud, So I've heard it said, (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CUSTOMER 3 (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Picking through the pockets of the English dead. CUSTOMER 4

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He made a tidy score from the spoils of war. We suddenly hear the voice of the landlord, Thenardier. H has been there all the time, asleep on a bench. He wakes from his drunken slumbers and roars out: THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My band of soaks, My den of dissolutes, My dirty jokes, my always pissed as newts, My sons of whores, Spend their lives in my inn! Homing pigeons homing in - They fly through my doors, And their money's as good as yours!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Thenardier is trying to sell something unappealing from her stall to a portly looking man when slushy snow from the stall's roof falls on the man's head. Madame Thenardier ushers him inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome, m'sieur! Sit yourself down And meet the best Innkeeper in town! Madame Thenardier pretends to accidentally drop a comb fr her hair and the customer helpfully picks it up, allowing Madame Thenardier to pick his wallet from a back pocket a he stands up. Monsieur Thenardier takes his coat which allows the couple to see the customer transfer a pocket watch from coat to jacket pocket. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As for the rest - All of them crooks Rooking the guests And cooking the books. Seldom do you see Honest men like me A gent of good intent Who's content to be - He pours a strong drink for the new customer -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master of the house! Doling out the charm Ready with a handshake And an open palm Thenardier has thieved the pocket watch using his handsha as a distraction. He passes this off to Madame Thenardier THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tells a saucy tale Makes a little stir Customers appreciate a bon-viveur Glad to do a friend a favour Doesn't cost me to be nice But nothing gets you nothing Everything has got a little price! THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master of the house! Keeper of the zoo! Ready to relieve'em Of a sou or two - (serving wine)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watering the wine

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thenardier is pissing into the very wine bottle he's usin serve the customer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Making up the weight Picking up their knick-knacks When they can't see straight Everybody loves a landlord Everybody's bosom friend! I do whatever pleases - Jesus! Won't I bleed'em in the end!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Madame Thenardier's stall, a frost fair customer is covered by snow, only this time we realise Madame Thenard is responsible for pushing the snow off the awning with a stick. THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master of the house! Quick to catch your eye (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never wants a passer-by To pass him by! Madame Thenardier ushers the customer inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again Madame Thenardier drops her comb in front of the ne customer but this time the thieving is foiled by little Cosette who helpfully picks it up. Over the chorus she sh at little Cosette to get out. THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Servant to the poor Butler to the great Comforter, philosopher and lifelong mate Everybody's boon companion Everybody's chaperone - THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But lock up your valises - Jesus! Won't I skin you to the bone! A FAMILY enters the inn. Thenardier fusses over them. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Enter, messieurs! Lay down yer load Unlace yer boots And rest from the road. This weighs a ton Travel's a curse But here we strive To lighten your purse. He's got the father's purse out, and is removing notes. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here the goose is cooked Here the fat is fried And nothing's overlooked Till I'm satisfied - Food beyond compare Food beyond belief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thenardier shows off the secrets of the squalid kitchen - every possible animal being used to make mince meat. THENARDIER V/O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mix it in a mincer And pretend it's beef Kidney of a horse (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER V/O (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liver of a cat Filling up the sausages With this and that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thenardier serves the disgusting food that we've seen him create in the flashback to the family. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Residents are more than welcome Bridal suite is occupied

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A groom and bride consummate their union. Thenardier is going through the groom's trousers. THENARDIER V/O

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reasonable charges Plus some little extras on the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charge'em for the lice Extra for the mice Two percent for looking in the mirror twice. Here a little slice There a little cut Three percent for sleeping with the window shut. When it comes to fixing prices There are lots of tricks he knows How it all increases All those bits and pieces - Jesus! It's amazing how it grows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thenardier comes out of the inn, backed by a posse of his gang of loyal customers, and takes control of a brass ban sing to the Frost Fair. THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master of the house! Quick to catch your eye Never wants a passer-by To pass him by!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Further down the street, carrying her empty buckets, Cose turns to look sadly back at the cheery sight. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Servant to the poor Butler to the great Comforter, philosopher and lifelong mate Everybody's boon companion Gives'em everything he's got -                            The Portly Customer has discovered he's been robbed. He comes out to protest, holding out his emptied wallet. At once two of Thenardier's thugs grab him and hustle him of THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dirty bunch of geezers Jesus! What a sorry little lot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Madame Thenardier approaches a handsome soldier who is drinking at a table by the fire in the inn. She sits on h lap and gets him to look back at Thenardier, so allowing to see inside his coat and spot his wallet. MADAME THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to dream That I would meet a prince But God almighty Have you seen what's happened since? `Master of the house' Isn't worth my spit! Comforter, philosopher And lifelong shit! Cunning little brain Regular Voltaire Thinks he's quite a lover But there's not much there. As Madame Thenardier reaches for the man's groin, she lif his wallet skillfully and hands it off to Monsieur Thenardier. THENARDIER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a cruel trick of nature Landed me with such a louse. God knows how I've lasted Living with this bastard in the house! She pulls the young man into a dance, enabling her to ste everything else of value he has. Father Christmas has als been lured from the frost fair and the Thenardiers slit h presents sack and exchange it for a sack containing snow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS Master of the house! MADAME THENARDIER Master and a half! THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS Comforter, philosopher - MADAME THENARDIER Don't make me laugh! THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS Servant to the poor Butler to the great - MADAME THENARDIER Hypocrite and toady And inebriate! THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS Everybody bless the landlord! Everybody bless his spouse! THENARDIER Everybody raise a glass! MADAME THENARDIER Raise it up the master's arse! THENARDIER/CUSTOMERS Everybody raise a glass to the master of the house!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cosette has filled her buckets at the well in the wood, a is now heading back. Through the dark trees ahead we glim the cheerful lights of the Frost Fair and the distant inn She goes slowly, because the buckets are heavy. She hums herself to keep her spirits up, a wordless verse of `Cast on a Cloud'. After a few steps she pauses to rest the weight of the buckets. Strong arms reach for the buckets and lift them out of he hands. She looks up, amazed. There's Valjean. VALJEAN Hush now, do not be afraid of me. Don't cry. Show me where you live. (more)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VALJEAN (cont'd)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
